value.name: ZERO
value.brief: Sets the stencil buffer value to 0

value.name: REPLACE
value.brief: Sets the stencil value to ref

value.name: INCR
value.brief: Increments stencil buffer value, clamps to max

value.name: DECR
value.brief: Descrements stencil buffer value, clamps to min

value.name: INVERT
value.brief: Bitwise inverts the current stencil buffer value

value.name: INCR_WRAP
value.brief: Increments stencil buffer value, wraps around

value.name: DECR_WRAP
value.brief: Decrements stencil buffer value, wraps around

enum.name: BLEND_EQ
enum.doc: determines how pixel blending combines source and destination

value.name: G8R8I
value.brief: Also used for X8R8I X8R8UI G8R8UI

value.name: A8B8G8R8I
value.brief: Also used for X8B8G8R8I X8B8G8R8UI A8B8G8R8UI

value.name: G16R16I
value.brief: Also used for X16R16I X16R16UI G16R16UI

value.name: A16B16G16R16I
value.brief: Also used for X16B16G16R16I X16B16G16R16UI A16B16G16R16UI

stripe.name: VS
stripe.doc: The vertex shader to be used for 3D rendering is configured here.

reg32.name: END_PC
reg32.doc: index of last instruction + 1

reg32.name: OUTPUT
reg32.doc: Each bitfield (up to 16 in total) contains a temporary register number that is used as output at the end of the shader for that varying.

reg32.name: INPUT
reg32.doc: Each bitfield (up to 16 in total) contains the number of a temporary register that is assigned the input for that attribute at the beginning of shader execution.

reg32.name: RANGE
reg32.brief: Defines the range within which VS instructions are executed, relative to start of the state area

reg32.name: UNIFORM_BASE
reg32.brief: Offset applied to VS uniform loads (granularity is 4-vectors)

bitfield.name: ENABLE
bitfield.brief: Enables loading of shader instructions from memory

reg32.name: INST_ADDR
reg32.brief: Memory address of shader instructions, must be aligned to 0x100

reg32.name: SAMPLER_BASE
reg32.brief: Offset value applied to sampler index from VS

reg32.name: ICACHE_INVALIDATE
reg32.doc: Kernel driver writes value with all 5 bits set to here to flush ICACHE.

bitfield.name: SIZE
bitfield.brief: Size of work group minus one

bitfield.name: COUNT
bitfield.brief: Number of work groups minus one

stripe.name: CL
stripe.doc: The thread walker drives shaders in a predefined grid for GPGPU computing (OpenCL). These states are not used for normal rendering.

bitfield.name: VALUE_ORDER
bitfield.brief: Order in which global/local ids are in temp registers
bitfield.doc: At the beginning of a thread the first temporary registers will contain the local and global ids. This value what ids will be present, and in which order.

reg32.name: KICKER
reg32.doc: Write some value to this register to kick off thread walker

stripe.name: PA
stripe.doc: Primitive assembly assembles primitives (tris, quads, lines, points etc) from vertices for 3D rendering. Viewport scaling, line width and point size is configured here.

reg32.name: LINE_WIDTH
reg32.brief: Half of line width in pixels

reg32.name: SYSTEM_MODE
reg32.doc: 0x11 for OpenGL, 0x00 for D3D9

reg32.name: CONFIG
reg32.doc: These can be set either per group of bits, or all at once, by using masking flags. Each group of state flags has a masking flag that prevents overwriting the flags in that group.

bitfield.name: POINT_SIZE_ENABLE
bitfield.doc: Adds an extra output to VS (at the end).

value.name: CW
value.brief: Orientation of front-facing polygons is clockwise

value.name: CCW
value.brief: Orientation of front-facing polygons is counter-clockwise

reg32.name: WIDE_LINE_WIDTH0
reg32.brief: Line width, used when PA.CONFIG.WIDE_LINE set

reg32.name: WIDE_LINE_WIDTH1
reg32.brief: Another line width, used when PA.CONFIG.WIDE_LINE set

reg32.name: SHADER_ATTRIBUTES
reg32.doc: Flags word per shader attribute. I suspect that these determine the type of interpolation (color, perspective, linear, ...).

bitfield.name: BYPASS_FLAT
bitfield.brief: Bypass flat shading for this varying

reg32.name: VIEWPORT_UNK00A80
reg32.doc: Blob sets this based on size of the viewport or render target 256 x 256 -> 1.526625e-05 ~= 1/65504 1920 x 1080 -> 1.144968e-04 ~= 1/8734 Works out to 5.96337734375e-08 * width. I have not yet found any visual indication of what it does.

reg32.name: VIEWPORT_UNK00A84
reg32.doc: I found that lower values than 8192 scale the point size down.

reg32.name: FLAGS
reg32.doc: The Vivante driver sets these at context setup, they seem to be some global bypasses and CYA flags.

reg32.name: ZFARCLIPPING
reg32.doc: This is set by the Vivante driver to 0x00000000 if the chipMinorFeatures4_ZFIXES bit is set (as on gc3000), 0x38000000 otherwise (gc2000).

reg32.name: VS_OUTPUT_COUNT
reg32.brief: Looks like a duplicate of VS output count

stripe.name: SE
stripe.doc: The setup engine takes care of scissor, clipping, and depth scale.

stripe.name: RA
stripe.doc: Configuration for the rasterizer. This mainly controls multisampling.

stripe.name: PS
stripe.doc: The Pixel (Fragment) shader to use is configured here

reg32.name: OUTPUT_REG
reg32.brief: Register that will contain output color

reg32.name: RANGE
reg32.brief: Defines the range within which PS instructions are executed, relative to start of the state area

reg32.name: UNIFORM_BASE
reg32.brief: Offset applied to PS uniform loads (granularity is 4-vectors)

reg32.name: INST_ADDR
reg32.brief: Memory address of shader instructions, must be aligned to 0x100

reg32.name: SAMPLER_BASE
reg32.brief: Offset value applied to sampler index from PS

stripe.name: GS
stripe.doc: The Geometry shader to use is configured here

stripe.name: PE
stripe.doc:
The Pixel Engine takes care of writing pixels to the framebuffer, doing blending, depth testing and alpha testing if needed.
Some flags can be set either per group of bits, or all at once, by using masking flags. Each group of state flags has a masking flag that when set prevents overwriting the flags in that group. These will be called FOO_MASK if the state to be masked is called FOO.

bitfield.name: DISABLE_ZS
bitfield.doc:
Completely disabled writing to depth stencil buffer on older hardware.
On GC7000+ this bit does something else and needs to be always enabled, otherwise rendering with TS-backed depth buffer tends to crash. (it might actually be the new bit for supertiling, a similar move that happened in PE.COLOR_FORMAT with SUPER_TILED_NEW)

reg32.name: STENCIL_CONFIG
reg32.doc: Warning: confusing terminology. WRITE_MASK is the stencil write mask, the state bits can be masked with WRITE_MASK_MASK.

bitfield.name: OVERWRITE
bitfield.brief: Set to 1 when destination fully overwritten, so no alpha blending and masked components

value.name: D24S8
value.brief: 24 bit depth (+8 bit stencil or padding)

stripe.name: CO
stripe.doc: Hardware composer. This functionality is present on some GCxxxx chips and allows for blending surfaces together with Porter-Diff composition methods, to accelerate the likes of Surfaceflinger (Android).

stripe.name: RS
stripe.doc:
To my current understanding, RESOLVE is a multifunctional copy/fill engine that can copy blocks of pixels from one place in memory to another, actually clearing tiles that are marked as cleared in the process. Other capabilities are:
- Conversion between pixel formats - Downsampling (2x horizontal or horizontal and vertical) - Fill with constant value - Partial fill (only clear part of the channels) - Tiling / untiling, for normal tiled and supertiled surfaces - Swap blue and red channels, flip image in Y - Endian swapping - Fill tiles that are marked as 'cleared' in the Tile Status
The following render target tilings are possible:
A B C 0 x x Linear 1 0 0 Tiled (4x4, like textures) 1 1 0 Supertiled (64x64) 1 0 1 Multi-tiled (4x4, like textures) 1 1 1 Multi-supertiled (64x64)
A) tiled: SOURCE_TILED, DEST_TILED in CONFIG word B) supertiled: TILING bit in SOURCE_STRIDE / DEST_STRIDE C) multi: MULTI bit in SOURCE_STRIDE / DEST_STRIDE
GC2000 and other GPUs with multiple pixel pipes have additional multi-pipe tiling formats, which are used by the PE when rendering as an extra form of paralelism. When multitiling the image is divided up vertically into separate units with their own starting address.

reg32.name: KICKER
reg32.doc: Write some value to this register to kick off resolver

bitfield.name: SOURCE_FORMAT
bitfield.doc: For clear operations, this specifies the format that CLEAR_CONTROL.BITS is in.

reg32.name: WINDOW_SIZE
reg32.doc: When downsampling the source and destination size will be different. In this case, the WINDOW_SIZE will be the (unscaled) source size.

bitfield.name: BITS
bitfield.brief: Affects which channels of which tiles are cleared
bitfield.doc:
Four groups (per tile) of four bits (per channel) that affect which channels of which tiles are cleared. In mode 'enabled' only the lower four bits are used, in 'enabled2' all four groups are used.
Components that are disabled are not written at all by the clear logic (they keep their old value) they are not copied from the source.

bitfield.name: MODE
bitfield.doc: Depending on the clear mode, the RS does different things: - If disabled, it is a copy engine - If enabled, it fills the target area with FILL_VALUE(0) and disregards the source - If enabled2, it fills the target area with the four FILL_VALUEs (results in vertical stripes of width 4, at least with supertiled target) and disregards the source.

value.name: ENABLED4
value.brief: Clear with four alternating tile values

reg32.name: KICKER_INPLACE
reg32.brief: Triggers an in-place resolve, where the value is the number of tiles
reg32.doc:
GC3000 and up: triggers an in-place resolve.
Seems the value written is the number of tiles to process. After writing this value, all tiles that are not yet filled according to TS will be filled in, without a copy operation.
The blob queues the following state changes afterwards: GL.FLUSH_CACHE := COLOR DUMMY.DUMMY := 0x0

stripe.name: TS
stripe.doc: Tile status block contains information about the tiles to be resolved. It is used by the PE (to read/update tile status) as well as the RS (to read tile status for source).

reg32.name: MEM_CONFIG
reg32.doc: Tile status config. Setting this value to 0 disables tile status and makes the resolve work like a normal copy engine.

bitfield.name: DEPTH_AUTO_DISABLE
bitfield.brief: Auto disable fast clear for depth

bitfield.name: COLOR_AUTO_DISABLE
bitfield.brief: Auto disable fast clear for color

bitfield.name: COLOR_COMPRESSION
bitfield.doc:
The type of color compression used depends on the GPU. On older GPUs the color compression was a lossy format, specifically used when MSAA was enabled.
On GC7000 this field and COLOR_COMPRESSION_FORMAT seem to be set based on DEC400 enable/disable; if VIV_DISABLE_DEC400, this is set to 0 and COLOR_COMPRESSION_FORMAT also 0. If DEC400 enabled, this is (sometimes) set to 1 and COLOR_COMPRESSION_FORMAT is 3.

bitfield.name: HDEPTH_AUTO_DISABLE
bitfield.brief: Auto disable fast clear for hdepth

reg32.name: HDEPTH_STATUS_BASE
reg32.doc: Hierarchical Z allocates multiple depth buffers for one surface, which have their own TS.

reg32.name: HDEPTH_SIZE
reg32.brief: Size of hierarchical depth buffer divided by 16

reg32.name: COLOR_CLEAR_VALUE_EXT
reg32.doc: This is used along with TS.COLOR_CLEAR_VALUE to fill in tiles with a 64-bit pattern instead of a 32-bit pattern.

stripe.name: YUV
stripe.doc: The YUV tiler can combine planar YUV formats to RGB or non-planar YUV formats.

stripe.name: SAMPLER
stripe.doc: 8 fragment texture samplers, 4 vertex texture samplers

stripe.name: NTE
stripe.doc: Extra texture states for newer hardware. These exist if chipMinorFeatures2 bit 11 set.

stripe.name: SAMPLER
stripe.doc: 16 fragment texture samplers, 16 vertex texture samplers

reg32.name: DESCRIPTOR_FLUSH
reg32.doc: Kernel driver writes here to flush the TX descriptor cache

reg32.name: DESCRIPTOR_INVALIDATE
reg32.brief: Writing here invalidates a texture descriptor
reg32.doc: This state is written, once per descriptor, when the contents of a specific descriptor have changed and need to be re-fetched.

reg32.name: ADDR
reg32.doc: This points to a 256 byte, 64-byte aligned structure in memory with the actual texture configuration. See texdesc_3d.xml for the layout of texture descriptors.

reg32.name: SAMP_CTRL0

bitfield.name: MIP
bitfield.brief: Filter for filtering between mipmap levels

reg32.bitfield: To disable mipmapping, set this to NONE as well as set the minimum and maximum LOD level to 0..0.

stripe.name: SH
stripe.doc: Shader instruction memory on new hardware that supports more than 256, or more than 1024 shader instructions (different areas are used based on these cases).
